function_summary: NixOS configuration for enabling Bluetooth hardware support and management with Blueman GUI.
detailed_notes:
This module configures Bluetooth functionality on NixOS systems, enabling hardware support and user interface for device management.

Configuration Elements:

1. Hardware Enablement:
   - hardware.bluetooth.enable: Activates Bluetooth kernel modules and bluez service.
   - hardware.bluetooth.powerOnBoot: Automatically powers on the default Bluetooth controller at system startup.

2. Management Interface:
   - services.blueman.enable: Installs and starts Blueman, a GTK-based Bluetooth manager.
   - Provides GUI for pairing, connecting, and managing Bluetooth devices.

Benefits:
- Enables wireless connectivity for peripherals (keyboards, mice, headphones).
- User-friendly management through Blueman interface.
- Automatic power-on simplifies usage.

Security Considerations:
- Bluetooth protocols have known vulnerabilities; keep firmware updated.
- Blueman runs with user privileges; no elevated access.

Potential Issues:
- Assumes compatible Bluetooth hardware; may fail on unsupported controllers.
- Blueman is GTK-based; requires X11/Wayland environment.
- Power-on may drain battery on laptops if not needed.
- Conflicts possible with other Bluetooth managers.

Compatibility:
- Compatible with NixOS and bluez stack.
- Works with various Bluetooth controllers (USB, integrated).
- Blueman supports modern Bluetooth standards.

Integration Points:
- Imported in desktop/laptop machine configurations.
- Complements input device and audio configurations.
- Useful for user-facing systems.

Code Quality:
- Simple and focused configuration.
- Uses standard NixOS options.
- Easy to disable if not needed.

This module provides essential Bluetooth support for interactive NixOS systems.
reasoning: The file enables Bluetooth with bluez and Blueman. It sets power on boot for convenience. Evidence: Standard NixOS Bluetooth options. Assumptions: System has Bluetooth hardware, runs graphical environment.
